title: Bid to Unify House Democrats Faces Tests on Issues
summary: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez will meet to bridge differences. WASHINGTON-The tenuous peace deal struck by the Democratic leadership between its moderate and liberal flanks is facing a series of tests as lawmakers confront differences within the party on topics ranging from spending to impeachment and Israel.

title: Mueller Defends Investigation as 'Thorough' and 'Fair' in House Testimony
summary: Former special counsel repeatedly directed lawmakers to his report and didn't respond to Republican criticisms. Former special counsel Robert Mueller repeatedly directed lawmakers to his report on Russian election interference and provided clipped answers to questions during hearings Wednesday that provided more partisan jousting than fresh insight into his inquiry.

title: Northrop Grumman, General Dynamics Bolster Full-Year Profit Forecasts
summary: Aerospace-and-defense companies post gains in quarterly earnings, topping analysts' expectations. Northrop Grumman Corp. and General Dynamics Corp. , two of the largest aerospace-and-defense companies, raised their profit outlooks for the year as they posted second-quarter results that beat expectations.

title: House Panel Prepares Suit to Enforce McGahn Subpoena
summary: Dispute centers on whether former White House counsel's testimony about efforts to curtail Russia probe would be public or private. WASHINGTON-The House Judiciary Committee is preparing to file a lawsuit in the coming days to enforce a subpoena for testimony by former White House counsel Don McGahn, as the panel has so far failed to reach a deal with the White House over a central aspect of his testimony: whether it would be public or private.

title: Best Buy Promotes Insider to CFO
summary: Matt Bilunas will assume the CFO post vacated by Corie Barry, who was named chief executive this year. Best Buy Co. on Wednesday named Matt Bilunas, a 13-year veteran of the company, as its next chief financial officer.

title: PayPal Scales Back Outlook, Spooking Investors
summary: Shares fall after company warns full-year revenue is likely to be lower than previously forecast. Shares of PayPal Holdings Inc. fell more than 6% in aftermarket trading on Wednesday after the financial-technology company said delays in product integrations, as well as other factors, would cause its full-year revenue to be lower than it had previously predicted.

title: Facebook's Privacy Penalty
summary: The punishment is about as stiff as current law allows.. Rebuke or reprieve? That's the debate over the $5 billion settlement announced Wednesday between Facebook and the Federal Trade Commission for privacy violations. While the agreement stretches the law, it probably achieves the best possible outcome for users barring clearer privacy rules from Congress.

title: Two Uber Board Members Step Down
summary: Arianna Huffington and Benchmark's Matt Cohler had been vocal about changing ride-hailing firm's culture and oversight. Two Uber Technologies Inc. directors-including entrepreneur Arianna Huffington-are stepping down from the ride-hailing company's board, the company said Wednesday.

title: SoftBank Looks to Goldman, Apple for Sequel to $100 Billion Vision Fund
summary: Apple, Goldman Sachs and Kazakhstan government are among backers. title: MTA Board Approves Agency Overhaul to Cut Costs
summary: Reorganization calls for 2,700 job cuts; officials estimate $530 million in annual savings. New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority board voted Wednesday to implement a reorganization plan that could reshape the nation's largest transit agency.

title: Brazil Will Give Workers Up to $8 Billion to Spur Growth
summary: Government to distribute funds normally set aside for unemployed as economy struggles. BRASÍLIA-President Jair Bolsonaro will give Brazilians early access this year to as much as 30 billion reais ($8 billion) in funds normally set aside for the unemployed in an effort to spur the country's moribund economy.

title: 'Crisis in the Red Zone' Review: Blood Will Tell
summary: The author of "The Hot Zone" grippingly chronicles another Ebola outbreak, in 2014-16, and offers a grim forecast for future flare-ups.. HIV, the human immunodeficiency virus, made its presence felt beginning in 1981, first gradually and then dramatically. We now know that it "emerged" decades previously, crossing from an animal reservoir to a human host. It then smoldered in isolated individuals before conditions permitted it to spread explosively. HIV has since evolved before our eyes, becoming less aggressive and more insidious, especially in the West, but it is still a major health problem, nowhere more than in Africa.

title: Impeachment Limps On
summary: The Mueller hearing was a dud, but House Democrats probably won't be deterred.. Designed by their Democratic chairmen to strengthen the case for impeaching President Trump, the effort failed.

title: Trade Wars Are Sending Jobs Elsewhere
summary: Foreign investors are building fewer factories in the U.S.. The costs of America's trade disputes with the world continue to mount. Academic studies document clearly, for example, that new U.S. tariffs on washing machines and other products have raised U.S. consumer prices of those goods, thereby cutting into Americans' real incomes.

title: NYPD Arrests Man Accused of Throwing Water at Police

title: Facebook Settlement Vindicates Consumer Privacy
summary: The FTC imposes a historic fine and creates a strong protocol to prevent further abuses of data.. So it's important to understand what the case, which was settled Wednesday, was actually about: the privacy commitments Facebook made to its users and the government.

title: Xi Changed My Mind About Trump
summary: The president defends not only U.S. sovereignty but the entire world order.. At first I had no idea why President Trump talked so much about sovereignty. I've changed my mind. To be more precise, Xi Jinping changed it. Mr. Trump is the only thing that stands between us and a world dominated by China.

title: The Opposite Flaws of Trump and Mueller
summary: The rebel who tramples norms vs. the bureaucrat who evades responsibility for his own decisions.. They're an exquisite and excruciating pair of opposites: the compulsive rule-breaker and the morbid rule-follower, the man who takes personal credit for everything good that happens, even if it doesn't, and the man who attributes his every decision to norms and regulations. They seem to be archetypal: juvenile delinquent and Boy Scout, wildcat entrepreneur and organization man, artist and bureaucrat.

title: Improve, Don't Repeal, ObamaCare's Cadillac Tax
summary: It's the law's least popular provision, but its goal of discouraging lavish employer plans is worthy.. There's one provision of ObamaCare almost everyone wants to repeal. Last week the House voted 419-6 to repeal the so-called Cadillac tax, a 40% excise on high-cost employer-sponsored health insurance. The bill now moves to the Senate.

summary: Record deliveries prove meaningless for Elon Musk's challenged auto company. It is time for Elon Musk and Tesla shareholders to accept reality: The company's days as a growth darling are coming to an end.

summary: The special counsel hearings refute the case for impeachment.. The only person in Washington happier than Donald Trump about Robert Mueller's Wednesday appearance before Congress is Nancy Pelosi. The House Speaker's impeachment caucus had hoped the hearing would mobilize new public support despite her opposition, but it was more likely their last gasp.

title: A Cryptocurrency Evades Swipe-Fee Limits
summary: We need competitive markets and reasonable regulations like the Durbin Amendment to help keep these fees in check; letting Visa, Mastercard and Facebook run our currency is the wrong approach.. I was initially puzzled that your July 19 editorial "Cryptocurrency to the Rescue" tries to boost Facebook 's beleaguered Libra cryptocurrency proposal by attacking my 2010 amendment that reined in Visa and Mastercard's anticompetitive fixing of debit-card swipe fees. The issues seem unrelated, but then I saw the connection: Visa and Mastercard, which hate my amendment, are both angling to be founding members of the Libra Association which would oversee Facebook's currency.

title: European Governments Struggle to Build Coalition to Secure Persian Gulf
summary: Varying proposals haven't come together, as the U.S., Russia and Iran pursue their own plans amid tensions over seized tankers; shipping industry treads water. title: Identity Politics and Conflict in Washington
summary: It is shocking how utterly fast the House of Representatives was able to pass a condemnation resolution regarding the president's tweets. This proves that when it wants to, Congress can rapidly get something done.. Regarding your editorial "Pelosi's Glass House" (July 17): It is shocking how utterly fast the House of Representatives was able to muster itself to pass a condemnation resolution on July 16 regarding the president's tweets made not even two days earlier. Congress doesn't even work most Mondays. This proves that, when it wants to, it can rapidly get something done. I can think of scores of things that Congress needs to get done just as quickly. Let's start with the normal appropriation bills, debt limits, border security and immigration-system overhaul. Don't forget that the honorable members are working on a pay raise for themselves. This type of action by the House is part of the reason that a great portion of the American electorate holds Congress in contempt and the vast majority of Americans are in favor of term limits.

title: Johnson Takes the Helm in Britain, Gears Up for Brexit Battle

title: 'The Nightingale' Tells a Different Rape-Revenge Story
summary: 'Maybe revenge isn't as sweet as we would hope,' says director Jennifer Kent. It's easy to find movie heroines, wronged by men, who exact sweet revenge. With her second film, "The Nightingale," director Jennifer Kent knowingly upends that typical movie fantasy. The story's heroine, Clare, is a young Irish convict and servant in 1825 Tasmania, who sets out to avenge her rape and violence against her family. What sets the film apart, Ms. Kent said, is its focus on the effect of that quest on Clare. "Maybe revenge isn't as sweet as we would hope," she said. "The Nightingale," which won a special jury prize at the Venice Film Festival last fall, opens on Aug. 2.

title: France Moves to Lift Ban on Assisted Reproduction for Female Couples

title: A Mexico City Hotel for True Fans of Midcentury Modernism
summary: Resume Subscription. IF DON DRAPER, the adulterous ad man of "Mad Men," had ever gone to Mexico City, he would have stayed-and strayed-at the Camino Real Polanco. The most ambitious work of architect Ricardo Legorreta, with 712 rooms and 8 acres of gardens, the hotel was built for the 1968 summer Olympics as a key component in the city's massive spruce-up. It soon became an icon of Mexican Modernism, an architectural movement known for adventurously using geometric forms and eye-popping colors. Set in the gardens, a series of sloping low-rise structures evoked Aztec pyramids, a nod to the city's pre-Hispanic past. Other flourishes included hot-pink lattice gates and a fountain that erupts and swirls like an ocean during a storm. The interiors weren't demure either: The lobby appeared straight out of "The Jetsons" and the Blue Bar basked under neon lights. Despite its many distractions, the hotel served as the base for that year's Mexican athletes. The Games themselves were overshadowed by the politics of the day, marked by black-power protests, student riots and deadly clashes with armed forces-extreme even by 1968 standards.

title: Dunkin' Joins Meatless Rush With Beyond Patty
summary: Coffee chain adds plant-based sausage sandwich to menus in Manhattan. Dunkin' Brands Group Inc. is diving into the meat-replacement craze.

title: Is the Souvenir Cap the Ultimate Humblebrag?
summary: Everyone from former special counsel Robert Mueller to rapper Travis Scott has worn a baseball hat emblazoned with an insider's location, a deceptively unassuming garment. IN THE GIFT SHOP at the Chinati Foundation, an art museum full of minimalist masterworks in Marfa, Texas, visitors can purchase a $21 ball cap with "Chinati" stitched across the front in a neat sans-serif font. The hat, which is only available in that particular store-or, for the desperate, by phone-has become a curious "I was there" status symbol on the eastern seaboard. Frequent any quintessentially Brooklyn haunt, be it a coffee shop that serves flat whites or a craft-beer bar, and the odds are good you'll spot someone wearing a Chinati hat. It's not merely a hat; it declares (truthfully or not, reverently or irreverently) that you journeyed all those miles just to see some art in a dusty, underpopulated western Texas town.

title: U.S. New Home Sales Picked Up in June

title: Treasury Secretary Finds No Security Concerns With Google Work in China
summary: Findings rebuke claims made by billionaire investor Peter Thiel. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said he and President Trump have found no national security concerns about work that Google is doing in China, a rebuke of claims made by billionaire investor and Facebook Inc. board member Peter Thiel.

title: Mexican Inflation Slowed in Early July
summary: Food and beverage prices rose 0.54% from the end of June, and transportation costs were up 0.46%. MEXICO CITY-Mexican inflation edged closer to the central bank's target in the first half of July, with consumer prices rising moderately from the end of June, led by increases in food and transportation costs.

title: For Boris Johnson's Britain, a Cold World Awaits
summary: After leaving the EU, Britain would confront a more protectionist, nationalist world. For new U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson, Brexit isn't about Britain turning its back on the world. Quite the opposite: leaving the European Union is a chance for a sovereign Britain to stake out a new, more free position in the global economy.

title: Congressional Leaders Urge Members to Approve Spending Deal
summary: Bill prompts skepticism from both sides of the aisle, but is still expected to pass both chambers and get Trump's signature. WASHINGTON-Congressional leaders from both parties are urging lawmakers to support a two-year spending deal that also lifts the government's borrowing limit, seeking to ensure the compromise negotiated for weeks passes with broad bipartisan majorities.

title: GlaxoSmithKline's Vaccines Boost Its Revenue
summary: U.K. Drugmaker said revenue rose by 5% largely thanks to strong sales of its shingles vaccine. LONDON- GlaxoSmithKline PLC said newer vaccines and a tax windfall softened the bite of competition from a new generic version of its best-selling inhaler Advair in the second quarter.

title: Daimler's Travails Reflect Broader Pain in Luxury Autos
summary: New Daimler CEO seeks to address slowdown in sales by stemming the outflow of cash. BERLIN-Daimler AG, the maker of Mercedes-Benz cars, said Wednesday that it would step up cost-cutting efforts in the second half of the year after reporting the company's first quarterly loss in a decade.

title: The Therapy Session Between You, a Therapist-and Thousands of Listeners
summary: A wave of podcasts allows anybody with a Wi-Fi connection to be a fly on the couch as people bare their souls. Earlier this year, podcasting company Gimlet Media began recruiting volunteers for a new show with New York psychiatrist Alexandra Sacks. "Are you struggling with an issue related to motherhood?" producers asked on social media. "Do you want to talk about it with an expert for a new Gimlet podcast?"

title: Stocks to Watch: UPS, Caterpillar, Sprint, Chipotle, and More
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Wednesday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Tuesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: How Much Protein Do You Need a Day?
summary: Eight ounces of protein daily are enough in a balanced diet that includes fruits, vegetables and grains, our expert says. It's summer, the season when protein-rich burgers and steaks are sizzling on outdoor grills. That got us wondering: How much protein should an adult consume every day? Most dietitians consider these nutrients a building block of a healthy diet. Proteins, which are long chains of amino acids, are the basic components of tissue found in all human muscles and internal organs.

title: YouTube's Liza Koshy on Falling Asleep to Meditation Soundscapes
summary: 'Apparently it makes you smarter?' says the actor and comedian, whose YouTube comedy 'Liza on Demand' bows its second season in September. Number of unread emails:

title: A 'Lord of the Rings' Veteran's Favorite Things
summary: The celebrated composer Howard Shore on the objects he can't live without-including an imposing piece of armor gifted by director Peter Jackson. "THE WHITE CAPEZIOS on the left were a part of my onstage costume while I was the musical director of Saturday Night Live from 1975 to 1980. I have such fond memories of that period.

title: Tesla Expected to Cut Losses in Second Quarter: What to Watch
summary: Some analysts wonder whether the electric-car maker can meet its 2019 delivery target. Tesla is expected to release second-quarter earnings after the market closes Wednesday. Here's what you need to know:

title: As Fed Preps a Rate Cut, ECB Weighs Stimulus of Its Own
summary: Relaunching quantitative easing could trigger fresh tensions between the ECB and Germany. The eurozone's $13 trillion economy is faltering, buffeted by trade tensions and international uncertainties. Germany's mighty export machine is stalling and the political situation in Italy remains volatile.

title: Falling Real Yields Signal Economic Worry
summary: Decline in yield on 10-year Treasury inflation-protected securities has been especially persistent. Yields on U.S. government bonds have fallen broadly this year. But the decline in the yield on one particular type has been especially persistent and is, according to some investors, a sign of concern for the U.S. economy.

title: Trump Really Might Weaken the Dollar
summary: Currency intervention hasn't been tried by the U.S. for years, but don't count out an effort by the Trump administration to weaken the dollar. The Federal Reserve probably won't cut rates as much as President Trump thinks it should, but he has another tool he can use to stimulate the economy: He can sell the dollar.

title: Mercedes Maker Needs to Unload Freightliner
summary: Daimler's truck business performed much better than its Mercedes-Benz car division, highlighting the case for a split. While Mercedes-Benz cars lost money for Daimler in the second quarter, the German automotive conglomerate's truck division fired on all cylinders. The case for a split of these two world-class businesses has never seemed stronger.

title: Investors Wonder if the ECB Can Do Enough to Make a Difference
summary: The central bank meets Thursday with expectations high that it will ease policy, or at least promise that it will do so in coming months. The European Central Bank has convinced financial markets that it will act. The question is, among its grab bag of possible moves, will it do more than investors expect?

title: Crypto Promoter Makes Speedy Recovery After Being Too Ill to Meet Buffett
summary: Kidney stones were cited as the reason for the delaying of Mr. Sun's lunch meeting with the billionaire investor, for which the Chinese citizen paid $4.6 million in a charity auction. Cryptocurrency investor and entrepreneur Justin Sun said he is feeling better and is attempting to return to work by the end of the week, a day after he postponed a charity lunch with Warren Buffett because of a health issue.

title: The Municipal-Bond Market Is Now Controlled by Just a Few Firms
summary: Concentration benefits firms like Nuveen and Vanguard, as well as some investors, but critics see risks if the market cools. A few behemoths are increasingly dominating the municipal market, helping to lower prices for many investors but also sparking worries about concentration and influence.

title: Shanghai's Funhouse-Mirror Nasdaq Shows What's Wrong With Chinese Markets
summary: Even with improved listing rules, China's tech board is unlikely to flourish until its equity markets become less speculative. China wants its own Nasdaq to stop domestic tech stars from fleeing to list abroad. But its latest effort looks no more likely to be successful than the previous attempt.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: A Day-By-Day Look Back at the Moon Mission
On This Day of the Moon Mission: Splashdown
Inside Shipping's Record Cocaine Bust
summary: An audacious effort to use a 9,400-mile commercial trade lane as an international drug smuggling corridor came apart in a nighttime raid on a ship at sea. On a cloudy evening on June 16, the MSC Gayane was making its way into Delaware Bay for a stopover at the Port of Philadelphia when it was intercepted by boats carrying about a dozen armed U.S. Customs and Border Protection and other federal agents.

title: FBI Abandons Use of Term 'Black Identity Extremism'
summary: Bureau has reorganized domestic terrorism categorization in favor of 'racially motivated violent extremism' category. WASHINGTON-The Federal Bureau of Investigation's director said the bureau has abandoned the term "black identity extremism" as part of a broad reconceptualization of how it thinks about racially motivated crime.

title: Facebook Expected to Settle SEC Claims of Inadequate Disclosures Over Privacy Practices
summary: Pact to include fine larger than $100 million. The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to announce a settlement with Facebook Inc. on Wednesday related to claims it inadequately disclosed risks involving its privacy practices, a person familiar with the matter said.

title: Trump Wants to Punish Guatemala Over Failed 'Safe Third Country' Deal
summary: Guatemalan president had canceled U.S. trip to discuss agreement requiring migrants to seek asylum there. President Trump threatened to punish Guatemala for what he described as the country's reneging on a proposed deal to welcome Central American asylum seekers.

title: Facebook Settlement Requires Zuckerberg to Certify Privacy Protections
summary: Deal with Federal Trade Commission opens chief executive to potential liability for noncompliance. WASHINGTON-Facebook Inc. CEO Mark Zuckerberg will have to personally certify that the company is taking steps to protect consumer privacy under a settlement expected to be announced with the Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday, a person familiar with the matter said.

title: Visa Beats Projections on Higher Card Spending
summary: Chief Executive Al Kelly talks up card network's growing presence in fintech sector, possible Libra role. Visa Inc. reported strong financial results for the latest period on the back of higher card spending, as the company touted its push into the financial-technology sector, including its possible role in Facebook Inc.'s Libra project.
